subject: RE: [junit] Testing & Design (was: testing private methods)
msgSnippet: ... I am sorry that I made myself misunderstood in this way.  What I intended to say was: lets make the discussion clear for those who don t want to
messageBody:
> I'm not sure how you can separate the two discussions. Could
> you tell me how Unit Testing can be discussed without discussing
> its impact on design?

I am sorry that I made myself misunderstood in this way. What I
intended to say was: lets make the discussion clear for those who don't
want to participate in/read the 'testing private methods' thread, and
move to a 'Testing & Design' thread that brings the issue into better
focus. I see that my mistake was to omit 'private method' when I
mentioned separating Design and (private method) Unit testing.

What we could be saying then is:
- to those who want to test private methods, use another tool
- to those who want to learn about how testing can improve design, keep
on reading (this thread)

The statements above are not mutually exclusive, and, therefore, can be
done in conjunction.

Also, we could try to discover how many of this mailing list's readers
would actually like to be able to test private methods (democracy?). If
we find this to be a respectable percentage, we could then proceed to
find out whether they know of the benefits testing only public methods
has on design.

> [...] JUnit was not built for that purpose. Not only that, its
> creators feel
> (well Kent, anyway; I don't know how Erich feels) that one of
> the strengths
> of JUnit is that when the tests become painful to write,
> there is a tendency
> for the design to have an organic weakness that prevents the
> testing. As
> Kent says in this case, it's an opportunity to learn about
> your design.

I also know about Kent's position, and how much testing plays a part in
how HE sees development practices should be undertaken (XP, TDD).

>
> If you are going to say, "Take your testing/design
> discussions elsewhere,"

I am *really* sorry if my post could be misconstrued in that manner!
Once again, I believe I mentioned the fact that many an insight has been
gained from these discussions. Keep it up!

> It's all in how you define "unit". To me, it's the exported
> methods of a
> class or interface. Kent and Erich may define it differently.
> Clearly, you
> define it differently.

I was only voicing my opinion for the testing of private methods being
as it is a popular request. I myself believe in the benefits of testing
public methods only, and therefore have no need for that functionality.

I would add that, since testing of private methods is such a popular
request, JUnit's position on the matter should be clearly stated in the
documentation (README, index.html, FAQ, ...), and why (pointer to
Testing & Design discussions). [A quick search on Google revealed that
the only place private methods are mentioned on the junit.org site is
where JUnitX is mentioned.]

> You folks can test private methods until your brain pops out,
> but just don't
> expect JUnit to do it out of the box. It was never designed
> for that. It was
> never designed for that *on purpose*. I don't know why that
> is such a big
> deal.

And it isn't! I am just questioning whether *on purpose* is actually
the reason, or whether it was never envisaged to be used that way. Once
again, I am just trying to asses how many people would like this
functionality, and how many would reconsider after reading about how
Testing can affect Design.

Manuel Amago.
